bestBHT.bht: The Apostle Paul intentionally chose this citation as a direct reference to the covenant God made with the Jews. This covenant is not about political deliverance, but a religious and ethical transformation centered on the forgiveness of sins. Through the remission of their sins, the Jews will experience the fulfillment of God's covenant. This demonstrates a certainty of their call and conversion, reflecting God's faithfulness and the application of Christ's blood for the removal of their sins. The covenant stands as an unwavering testament to God's promises to His people.

Henry Alford: How came the Apostle, if he wished only to express the general thought, to choose just this citation, consisting of two combined passages?
I believe that the term 'shall come?' gave occasion for the quotation.
Yet it allowed of being indirectly applied to it.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: This is my covenant with them—literally, 'this is the covenant from me unto them.'

Those who believe that there are no predictions regarding the literal Israel in the Old Testament, that stretch beyond the end of the Jewish economy, are obliged to view these quotations by the apostle as mere adaptations of Old Testament language to express his own predictions.
But how forced this is, we shall presently see.
Albert Barnes: It is clear that he intended to express the general sense of the promises, as they were well known to the Jews, and as it was a point concerning which he did not need to argue or reason with them.
The time and manner in which this shall be, is not revealed.
God will doubtless convert the Jews, as he does the Gentiles, by human means, and in connection with the prayers of his people.
John Calvin: For we may gather from the words of the Prophet, — that God would have no more to do with his apostate people, until he should remit the crime of perfidy, as well as their other sins.

This also tends to confirm the subject in hand; for what he said of the conversion of a people who were so stubborn and obstinate, might have appeared incredible: he therefore removes this stumblingblock, by declaring that the covenant included a gratuitous remission of sins.

Some suppose that this is taken from Isaiah 27:9, where we find this phrase in the Septuagint, 'When I shall take away his sins,' but the Hebrew is somewhat different and farther from the form of the sentence here.
Philip Schaff: And this, i.e., what follows, is my covenant (the covenant from me) unto them."
And when I shall have forgiven their sins, this (this remission of sins conferred by me) will be my covenant to them ( i.e., they will therein have from me the execution of my covenant).
This reference to the taking away of sin was more appropriate to the Apostle’s purpose than the promise of the Spirit which follows in Isaiah 59:21.
Archibald T. Robertson: The from me covenant," "my side of the covenant I have made with them" (Sanday and Headlam).
Not a political deliverance, but a religious and ethical one.
Second aorist middle subjunctive of αφαιρεω, old and common verb, to take away.
John Gill: This is what God has promised to them in covenant, and he will be as good as his word; his covenant will never be broken, it will always remain sure and inviolable.
So that there is not only a possibility, and a probability, but even a certainty, of the call and conversion of the Jews.
But of the removing of their sins from themselves, from their consciences, by the application of the blood of Christ, and the imputation of his righteousness.
